revision.text:
{{Unbalanced|date=August 2014}} {{Patent law}}
Legal scholars, economists, activists, policymakers, industries, and trade organizations have held differing views on patents and engaged in contentious debates on the subject. Critical perspectives emerged in the nineteenth century that were especially based on the principles of [[free trade]].<ref name=Johns>Johns, Adrian: ''Piracy. The Intellectual Property Wars from Gutenberg to Gates''. The University of Chicago Press, 2009, {{ISBN|9780226401188}}</ref>{{rp|262–263}} Contemporary criticisms have echoed those arguments, claiming that patents block innovation and waste resources that could otherwise be used productively,<ref name='boldrin'>{{Cite book| last = Levine | first = David | authorlink = David K. Levine |author2=Michele Boldrin | authorlink2 = Michele Boldrin | title = Against intellectual monopoly | publisher = Cambridge University Press | date = 2008-09-07 | location = | url = http://www.dklevine.com/papers/imbookfinalall.pdf | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-521-87928-6 }}</ref> and also block access to an increasingly important "commons" of enabling technologies (a phenomenon called the [[tragedy of the anticommons]]),<ref name=anticommons>{{cite journal|last=Heller|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Heller (law professor)|author2=Eisenberg, Sue |date=May 1, 1998|title=Can Patents Deter Innovation? The Anticommons in Biomedical Research|journal=Science|volume=280|issue=5364|pages=698–701|pmid=9563938|doi=10.1126/science.280.5364.698|bibcode=}}</ref> apply a "one size fits all" model to industries with differing needs,<ref name=Posner>Richard A Posner for The Atlantic. July 12, 2012. [https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2012/07/why-there-are-too-many-patents-in-america/259725/ Why There Are Too Many Patents in America]</ref> that is especially unproductive for industries other than chemicals and pharmaceuticals and especially unproductive for the software industry.<ref name=BessenMeurer>Bessen, James, and Michael J. Meurer. Patent Failure: How Judges, Bureaucrats, and Lawyers Put Innovators at Risk. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2008. 2009 paperback edition, {{ISBN|9781400828692}}</ref> Enforcement by [[patent troll]]s of poor quality patents has led to criticism of the patent office as well as the system itself.<ref name=Barker>{{cite journal |last1=Barker |first1=David G. |year=2005 |title=Troll or no Troll? Policing Patent Usage with an Open Post-grant Review |journal=Duke Law & Technology Review |volume=9 |issue=11 |url=http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1129&context=dltr |accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref> Patents on pharmaceuticals have also been a particular focus of criticism, as the high prices they enable puts life-saving drugs out of reach of many people.<ref name="Banta, D.H. 2001">Banta D.H. (2001) [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11401589 Worldwide Interest in Global Access to Drugs] Journal of the American Medical Association 285 (22): 2844–46</ref> Alternatives to patents have been proposed, such [[Joseph Stiglitz]]'s suggestion of [[Prizes as an alternative to patents|providing "prize money"]] (from a "prize fund" sponsored by the government) as a substitute for the lost profits associated with abstaining from the monopoly given by a patent.<ref name=Stiglitz>Stiglitz, Joseph. Project Syndicate, 2007. [http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/stiglitz81/English project-syndicate.org]</ref>
These debates are part of a larger discourse on [[societal views on intellectual property|intellectual property protection]] which also reflects differing perspectives on [[anti-copyright|copyright]].
==History== Criticism of patents reached an early peak in Victorian Britain between 1850 and 1880, in a campaign against patenting that expanded to target [[copyright]] too and, in the judgment of historian Adrian Johns, "remains to this day the strongest [campaign] ever undertaken against intellectual property", coming close to abolishing patents.<ref name=Johns/>{{rp|247}} Its most prominent activists - [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]], [[William Robert Grove]], [[William Armstrong, 1st Baron Armstrong|William Armstrong]] and [[Robert Andrew Macfie|Robert A. MacFie]] - were inventors and entrepreneurs, and it was also supported by radical [[laissez-faire]] economists ([[The Economist]] published anti-patent views), law scholars, scientists (who were concerned that patents were obstructing research) and manufacturers.<ref name=Johns/>{{rp|249, 267, 270}} Johns summarizes some of their main arguments as follows:<ref name=Johns/>{{rp|273}}<ref>W.R. Grove: ''Suggestions for Improvements in the Administration of the Patent Law'', [[The Jurist]] n.s. 6 (January 28, 1860) 19-25 ([https://books.google.com/books?id=BWlMAAAAYAAJ online copy] at Google Books)</ref><ref>B. Sherman, L. Bently: ''The Making of Modern Intellectual Property Law'' (CUP 1999), 50-56 {{ISBN|9780521057134}}</ref> :''[Patents] projected an artificial idol of the single inventor, radically denigrated the role of the intellectual commons, and blocked a path to this commons for other citizens — citizens who were all, on this account, potential inventors too. [...] Patentees were the equivalent of squatters on public land — or better, of uncouth market traders who planted their barrows in the middle of the highway and barred the way of the people.'' Similar debates took place during that time in other European countries such as France, [[Prussia]], Switzerland and the Netherlands (but not in the USA).<ref name=Johns/>{{rp|248}}
Based on the criticism of patents as state-granted monopolies inconsistent with [[free trade]], the [[Netherlands]] abolished patents in 1869 (having established them in 1817), and did not reintroduce them until 1912.<ref name="kick">[[Ha Joon Chang|Chang, Ha-Joon]]. [http://www.paecon.net/PAEtexts/Chang1.htm "Kicking Away the Ladder: How the Economic and Intellectual Histories of Capitalism Have Been Re-Written to Justify Neo-Liberal Capitalism"]. ''[[Post-Autistic Economics Review]]''. 4 September 2002: Issue 15, Article 3. Retrieved on 8 October 2008.</ref> In Switzerland, criticism of patents delayed the introduction of patent laws until 1907.<ref name=Johns/>{{rp|248}}<ref name="kick"/>
==Contemporary arguments== Contemporary arguments have focused on ways that patents can slow innovation by: blocking researchers' and companies' access to basic, enabling technology, and particularly following the explosion of patent filings in the 1990s, through the creation of "patent thickets"; wasting productive time and resources fending off enforcement of low-quality patents that should not have existed, particularly by "patent trolls"; and wasting money on patent litigation. Patents on pharmaceuticals have been a particular focus of criticism, as the high prices they enable puts life-saving drugs out of reach of many people.
===Blocking innovation=== The most general argument against patents is that "intellectual property" in all its forms represents an effort to claim something that should not be owned, and harms society by slowing innovation and wasting resources.<ref name='boldrin'/>
Law professors [[Michael Heller (law professor)|Michael Heller]] and Rebecca Sue Eisenberg have described an ongoing [[tragedy of the anticommons]] with regard to the proliferation of patents in the field of [[biotechnology]], wherein intellectual property rights have become so fragmented that, effectively, no one can take advantage of them as to do so would require an agreement between the owners of all of the fragments.<ref name=anticommons/>
Some public campaigns for improving access to medicines and [[genetically modified food]] have expressed a concern for "preventing the over-reach" of intellectual property protection including patent protection, and "to retain a public balance in property rights".<ref name=sksell>Susan K Sell (2003), ''Private Power, Public Law: The Globalization of Intellectual Property Rights'', Cambridge, 2003 Cambridge University Press: [http://www.international-ul.com/pdf/ebook/1/_Uyz13PfFMbDE.pdf Cambridge Studies in International Relations: 88]; quoted from page 179, see also page 5.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QjSOfWPo6V4C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=genetically&f=false | title = Intellectual Property Rights and the Life Science Industries: A Twentieth Century History | isbn = 9780754621119 | author1 = Dutfield | first1 = Graham | year = 2003}}</ref> Some economists<ref name='boldrin'/> and scientists<ref name="Pearce J. M. 519–521">{{cite journal | author = Pearce J. M. | year = | title = Make nanotechnology research open-source | url = https://www.academia.edu/2174920/Make_nanotechnology_research_open-source | journal = Nature | volume = 491 | issue = | pages = 519–521 | doi = 10.1038/491519a | bibcode = 2012Natur.491..519P }}</ref> and law professors<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journals.lww.com/academicmedicine/fulltext/2002/12001/why_the_gene_patenting_controversy_persists.9.aspx |title=Why the Gene Patenting Controversy Persists : Academic Medicine |website=Journals.lww.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-04}}</ref> have raised concerns that patents retard technical progress and innovation. Others claim that patents have had no effect on research, based on surveys of scientists.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cook |first=Robert |url=http://www.thehastingscenter.org/Publications/BriefingBook/Detail.aspx?id=2174 |title=Gene Patents |publisher=The Hastings Center |date= |accessdate=2016-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scienceprogress.org/2009/10/do-gene-patents-hurt-research/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404034653/http://www.scienceprogress.org/2009/10/do-gene-patents-hurt-research/ |archivedate=2011-04-04 |df= }} </ref>
===Poor patent quality and patent trolls=== Patents have also been criticized for being granted on already-known inventions, with some complaining in the United States that the USPTO fails "to do a serious job of examining patents, thus allowing bad patents to slip through the system."<ref name="lemley">Lemley, Mark A., Rational Ignorance at the Patent Office (February 2001). Northwestern University Law Review, Vol. 95, No. 4, 2001. {{doi|10.2139/ssrn.261400}}</ref> On the other hand, some argue that because of low number of patents going into litigation, increasing quality of patents at [[patent prosecution]] stage increases overall legal costs associated with patents, and that current USPTO policy is a reasonable compromise between full trial on examination stage on one hand, and pure registration without examination, on the other hand.<ref name="lemley"/>
Enforcement of patents – especially patents perceived as being overly broad – by [[patent trolls]], has brought criticism of the patent system,<ref name=Barker/><ref>{{cite podcast |last1=Blumberg |first1=Alex |last2=Sydell |first2=Laura |url=http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/496/when-patents-attack-part-two |title=When Patents Attack... Part Two! |website=This American Life |publisher=Chicago Public Media |date=May 31, 2013 |accessdate=June 9, 2013}}</ref> though some commentators suggest that patent trolls are not bad for the patent system at all but instead realign market participant incentives, make patents more liquid, and clear the patent market.<ref>James F. McDonough III (2006) [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=959945&rec=1&srcabs=980776 The Myth of the Patent Troll] accessed 2010-01-17</ref>
Some patents granted in Russia have been denounced as [[pseudoscientific]] (for example, health-related patents using lunar phase or religious icons).<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.svobodanews.ru/Article/2007/03/30/20070330125156547.html | title = Бюллетень комиссии по борьбе с лженаукой. Ученые защищаются и атакуют | author = Илья Смирнов (Ilya Smirnov) | publisher = [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] | date = 2007-03-30 | accessdate = 2008-11-05 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/61FmrTnqN?url=http://www.svobodanews.ru/content/article/385525.html | archivedate = 2011-08-27 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://nkj.ru/texts/8976/ | title = Государство и лженаука | authors = Ю.Н.Ефремов, Р.Ф.Полищук | work = Наука и жизнь ([[Nauka i Zhizn]]) | accessdate = 2008-11-05 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/61FmupEg6?url=http://www.nkj.ru/texts/8976/index.php | archivedate = 2011-08-27 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sbras.ru/HBC/hbc.phtml?21+403+1 |title = Лженаука — путь в средневековье |author = Э. Кругляков |work = [[Наука в Сибири]] N 3 (2588) |date = 2007-01-18 |accessdate = 2008-11-05 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/61FmwLY3i?url=http://www.sbras.ru/HBC/hbc.phtml?21+403+1 |archivedate = 2011-08-27 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>
===Litigation costs=== According to [[James Bessen]], the costs of patent litigation exceed their investment value in all industries except chemistry and pharmaceuticals. For example, in the software industry, litigation costs are twice the investment value.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Bessen James | year = 2008 | title = The value of U.S. patents by owner and patent characteristics | url = | journal = Research Policy | volume = 37 | issue = 5| pages = 932–945 | doi=10.1016/j.respol.2008.02.005}}</ref> Bessen and Meurer also note that software and business model litigation accounts for a disproportionate share (almost 40 percent) of patent litigation cost, and the poor performance of the patent system negatively affects these industries.<ref name=BessenMeurer/><ref name=WheelerAllworth>Rob Wheeler and James Allworth for the Harvard Business Review. Sept 15, 2011 [https://hbr.org/2011/09/the-america-invents-act-rearra U.S. Patent Overhaul Won’t Help Innovators]</ref>
===Different industries but one law=== [[Richard Posner]] noted that the most controversial feature of US patent law is that it covers all industries in the same way, but not all industries benefit from the time-limited monopoly a patent provides in order to spur innovation.<ref name=Posner/> He said that while the pharmaceutical industry is "poster child" for the need for a twenty-year monopoly, since costs to bring to a market are high, the time of development is often long, and the risks are high, in other industries like software the cost and risk of innovation is much lower and the cycle of innovation is quicker, and obtaining and enforcing patents and defending against patent litigation is generally a waste of resources in those industries.<ref name=Posner/>
===Pharmaceutical patents=== Some have raised ethical objections specifically with respect to pharmaceutical patents and the high prices for medication that they enable their proprietors to charge, which poor people in the developed world, and developing world, cannot afford.<ref name="Banta, D.H. 2001"/><ref>Ferreira L. (2002) [http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3874&context=flr&sei-redir=1& Access to Affordable HIV/AIDS Drugs: The Human Rights Obligations of Multinational Pharmaceutical Corporations] Fordham Law Review 71(3):1133–79</ref> Critics also question the rationale that exclusive patent rights and the resulting high prices are required for pharmaceutical companies to recoup the large investments needed for research and development.<ref name="Banta, D.H. 2001"/> One study concluded that marketing expenditures for new drugs often doubled the amount that was allocated for research and development.<ref>Barton J.H. and Emanuel, E.J. (2005) [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16249422 The Patents-Based Pharmaceutical Development Process: Rationale, Problems and Potential Reforms] Journal of the American Medical Association 294(16): 2075–82</ref>
In 2003, [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) reached an agreement, which provides a developing country with options for obtaining needed medications under [[compulsory licensing]] or importation of cheaper versions of the drugs, even before patent expiration.<ref>[http://www.wto.org/english/news_e/pres03_e/pr350_e.htm Decision removes final patent obstacle to cheap drug imports]</ref>
In 2007 the government of Brazil declared [[Merck & Co.|Merck]]'s [[efavirenz]] anti-retroviral drug a "public interest" medicine, and challenged Merck to negotiate lower prices with the government or have Brazil strip the patent by issuing a compulsory license.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.newsrx.com/newsletters/Health-and-Medicine-Week/2004-08-02/080220043339965W.html | title = Drugs give HIV patients longer lives in victory for anti-patent activists| publisher =Health & Medicine Week | date = August 2004}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated6>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/5027532.stm | last = Anderson | first = Tatum | title = Africa rises to HIV drug challenge| publisher =BBC News |date=June 2006}}</ref><ref name=gay>{{cite web |url= http://www.gay.com/news/article.html?2007/05/03/6 | title = Brazil’s HIV-drug break down| publisher =gay.com |date=May 2007}}</ref>
It is reported that [[Ghana]], [[Tanzania]], the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] and [[Ethiopia]] have similar plans to produce generic antiviral drugs. [[Western world|Western]] pharmaceutical companies initially responded with legal challenges, but some have now promised to introduce alternative pricing structures for developing countries and NGOs.<ref name=autogenerated6 /><ref name=gay />
In July 2008 Nobel Prize-winning scientist Sir [[John Sulston]] called for an international biomedical treaty to clear up issues over patents.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/7490384.stm | last = McGrath | first = Matt | title = Sulston argues for openmedicine| publisher =BBC News |date=July 2008}}</ref>
In response to these criticisms, one review concluded that less than 5 percent of medicines on the [[essential drugs|World Health Organization's list of essential drugs]] are under patent.<ref name="PoIP">Ghafele R (2008) [http://www.ip-institute.org.uk/pdfs/Perceptions%20of%20IP.pdf Perceptions of Intellectual Property: A Review] London: Intellectual Property Institute</ref> Also, the pharmaceutical industry has contributed US$2 billion for healthcare in developing countries, providing HIV/AIDS drugs at lower cost or even free of charge in certain countries, and has used differential pricing and parallel imports to provide medication to the poor.<ref name="PoIP" /> Other groups are investigating how social inclusion and equitable distribution of research and development findings can be obtained within the existing intellectual property framework, although these efforts have received less exposure.<ref name="PoIP" />
Quoting a [[World Health Organization]] report, Trevor Jones (director of research and development at the Wellcome Foundation, as of 2006) argued in 2006 that patent monopolies do not create [[monopoly pricing]]. He argued that the companies given monopolies "set prices largely on the willingness/ability to pay, also taking into account the country, disease and regulation" instead of receiving competition from legalized generics.<ref name=autogenerated6 />
==Proposed alternatives to the patent system== Alternatives have been discussed to address the issue of financial incentivization to replace patents. Mostly, they are related to some form of direct or indirect government funding. One example is [[Joseph Stiglitz]]'s idea of [[Prizes as an alternative to patents|providing "prize money"]] (from a "prize fund" sponsored by the government) as a substitute for the lost profits associated with abstaining from the monopoly given by a patent.<ref name=Stiglitz/> Another approach is to remove the issue of financing development from the private sphere altogether, and to cover the costs with direct government funding.<ref>Baker, Dean. "The Reform of Intellectual Property". post-autistic economics review, issue no. 32, 5 July 2005, article 1, [http://www.paecon.net/PAEReview/issue32/Baker32.htm Paecon.net]</ref>

{{pp-move-indef}} {{short description|The indo-American astronaut and United States Navy officer }} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox astronaut | name = Sunita L. Williams | image = Sunita Williams in 2018.jpg | type = [[NASA]] Astronaut | status = Active | birth_place = [[Euclid, Ohio]], [[U.S.]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|9|19}} | occupation = [[Test pilot]] | rank = {{Dodseal|USNO6|25}} [[Captain (United States O-6)|Captain]], [[United States Navy|USN]] | selection = [[NASA Astronaut Group 17]] | space_time = 321days 17 hours 15 minutes | evas = 7 | eva_time = 50 hours
| missions = [[STS-116]]/[[STS-117|117]] ([[Expedition 14]]/[[Expedition 15|15]]), [[Soyuz TMA-05M]] ([[Expedition 32]]/[[Expedition 33|33]]) | insignia = [[File:STS-116 emblem.svg|35px|STS-116]] [[File:ISS Expedition 14 patch.svg|35px|ISS Expedition 14]] [[File:ISS Expedition 15 patch.svg|35px|ISS Expedition 15]] [[File:STS-117 patch new2.svg|35px|STS-117]] [[File:Soyuz-TMA-05M-Mission-Patch.png|35px|Soyuz TMA-05M]] [[File:ISS Expedition 32 Patch.svg|35px|Expedition 32]] [[File:ISS Expedition 33 Patch.svg|35px|Expedition 33]] }}
'''Sunita Pandya Lyn Williams'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/astronauts/english/williams_sunita.htm |title=Astronaut Biography: Sunita Williams |work=SpaceFacts.de |accessdate=March 17, 2013}}</ref><ref>https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/williams-s.pdf</ref> (born September 19, 1965) is an American [[astronaut]] and [[United States Navy]] officer of [[Indian Americans|Indo]]-[[Slovenes|Slovenian]] descent. She formerly held the records for total [[spacewalk]]s by a woman (seven) and most spacewalk time for a woman (50 hours, 40 minutes).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Garcia|first1=Mark|title=Peggy Whitson Breaks Spacewalking Record|url=https://blogs.nasa.gov/spacestation/2017/03/30/peggy-whitson-breaks-spacewalking-record/|website=NASA blog|publisher=NASA|accessdate=30 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="bio1">{{cite web |url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/williams-s.html |title=Sunita L. Williams (Commander, USN) |accessdate=December 19, 2007 |publisher=[[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] |year=2007 |author=[[NASA]]}}</ref><ref name="EVArec">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/spacewalking-astronauts-conquer-stiff-bolt-install-key-power-unit-on-2nd-trip-outside/2012/09/05/d872ab40-f784-11e1-a93b-7185e3f88849_story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120908051918/http://www.washingtonpost.com/business/spacewalking-astronauts-conquer-stiff-bolt-install-key-power-unit-on-2nd-trip-outside/2012/09/05/d872ab40-f784-11e1-a93b-7185e3f88849_story.html |archive-date=September 8, 2012 |title=Spacewalking astronauts conquer stiff bolt, install key power unit on 2nd trip outside |accessdate=September 6, 2012 |year=2012 |agency=Associated Press |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="Malik">{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/070208_exp14_eva4wrap.html |title=Orbital Champ: ISS Astronaut Sets New U.S. Spacewalk Record |access-date=December 19, 2007 |publisher=Space.com |year=2007 |author=Tariq Malik}}</ref> Williams was assigned to the [[International Space Station]] as a member of [[Expedition 14]] and [[Expedition 15]]. In 2012, she served as a [[flight engineer]] on [[Expedition 32]] and then commander of [[Expedition 33]].
==Early life and education== Sunita Williams was born in [[Euclid, Ohio]], to [[Indian American]] [[neuroanatomist]] [[Deepak Pandya]] and [[Slovene American]] Ursuline Bonnie (Zalokar) Pandya, who reside in [[Falmouth, Massachusetts]]. She is the youngest of three children. Her brother Jay Thomas is four years older and her sister Dina Annadj is three years older. Williams' paternal family is from [[Jhulasan]], [[Mehsana]] district in [[Gujarat]], India, while her maternal great-grandmother Mary Bohinc (originally Marija Bohinjec), born in [[Leše, Tržič|Leše]], Slovenia, immigrated to America as an eleven-year-old with her mother, 1891 [[Slovenes#Emigration|Slovene emigrant]] Ursula (Strajhar) Bohinac.<ref name="Ancestry_Slovenia">[http://www.delo.si/novice/slovenija/sunita-williams-spet-v-svoji-pradomovini.html Sunita Williams in her maternal ancestors' homeland one more time], [[Delo]], March 26, 2013.</ref><ref name="Ancestry_India">[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-03-31/us-canada-news/38162229_1_sunita-williams-astronaut-gujarat-technical-university Sunita Williams to start her India trip from April 1], [[The Times of India]], March 31, 2013.</ref>
Williams graduated from [[Needham High School]] in [[Needham, Massachusetts]], in 1983. She received a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[physical science]] from the [[United States Naval Academy]] in 1987, and a [[Master of Science]] degree in Engineering Management from [[Florida Institute of Technology]] in 1995.<ref name="bio1" />
==Military career== Williams was commissioned an ensign in the United States Navy in May 1987. After a six-month temporary assignment at the Naval Coastal System Command, she was designated a Basic Diving Officer. She next reported to the [[Naval Air Training Command]], where she was designated a [[United States Naval Aviator|Naval Aviator]] in July 1989. She received initial [[H-46 Sea Knight]] training in Helicopter Combat Support Squadron 3 ([[HSC-3|HC-3]]), and was then assigned to Helicopter Combat Support Squadron 8 ([[HSC-8|HC-8]]) in [[Norfolk, Virginia]], with which she made overseas deployments to the Mediterranean, Red Sea and the Persian Gulf for [[Operation Desert Shield]] and [[Operation Provide Comfort]]. In September 1992, she was the Officer-in-Charge of an H-46 detachment sent to [[Miami, Florida]], for [[Hurricane Andrew]] relief operations aboard {{USS|Sylvania|AFS-2|6}}. In January 1993, Williams began training at the [[U.S. Naval Test Pilot School]]. She graduated in December, and was assigned to the Rotary Wing Aircraft Test Directorate as an H-46 Project Officer and [[V-22 Osprey|V-22]] chase pilot in the [[T-2 Buckeye|T-2]]. Later, she was assigned as the squadron Safety Officer and flew test flights in the [[SH-60 Seahawk|SH-60B/F]], [[UH-1]], [[AH-1W]], [[Kaman SH-2 Seasprite|SH-2]], [[SH-3 Sea King|VH-3]], H-46, [[CH-53]], and the [[H-57 Sea Ranger|H-57]]. In December 1995, she went back to the Naval Test Pilot School as an instructor in the Rotary Wing Department and as the school's Safety Officer. There she flew the [[Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk|UH-60]], [[OH-6 Cayuse|OH-6]], and the [[Bell OH-58 Kiowa|OH-58]]. She was then assigned to {{USS|Saipan|LHA-2|6}} as the Aircraft Handler and the Assistant Air Boss. Williams was deployed on ''Saipan'' in June 1998 when she was selected by [[NASA]] for the astronaut program.<ref name="bio1" /> She has logged more than 3,000 flight hours in more than 30 aircraft types.<ref name="bio1" />
==NASA career== [[File:Sunita Williams astronaut spacewalk.jpg|thumb|250px|Astronaut Sunita L. Williams, STS-116 mission specialist, participates in the mission's third planned session of extravehicular activity (EVA)]]
Sunita Williams began her Astronaut Candidate training at the [[Johnson Space Center]] in August 1998.Following are the space mission undertaken by Sunita Williams<ref name="bio1" />
===STS-116=== Williams was launched to the International Space Station (ISS) with [[STS-116]], aboard the Space Shuttle [[Space Shuttle Discovery|''Discovery'']], on December 9, 2006, to join the [[Expedition 14]] crew. In April 2007, the Russian members of the crew rotated, changing to [[Expedition 15|Expedition]] .
===Expeditions 14 and 15=== [[File:ISS-14 Williams Marathon.jpg|thumb|250px|Williams became the first person to run a [[marathon]] from the space station on April 16, 2007]] After launching aboard the Shuttle ''Discovery'', Williams arranged to donate her pony tail to [[Locks of Love]]. Fellow astronaut [[Joan Higginbotham]] cut her hair aboard the International Space Station and the ponytail was brought back to Earth by the [[STS-116]] crew.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-121906a.html |publisher=CollectSpace.com |author=CollectSpace.com |title=Astronaut cuts her hair in space for charity |date=2006-12-20 |access-date=2007-06-08}}</ref> Williams performed her first [[extra-vehicular activity]] on the eighth day of the STS-116 mission. On January 31, February 4, and February 9, 2007, she completed three spacewalks from the ISS with [[Michael López-Alegría]]. During one of these walks, a camera became untethered, probably because the attaching device failed, and floated off to space before Williams could react.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adorama.com/catalog.tpl?op=NewsDesk_Internal&article_num=122206-1 |title=Astronaut's Camera is Lost In Space |publisher=Adoama.com |date=2006-12-22 |accessdate=2007-06-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927075451/http://www.adorama.com/catalog.tpl?op=NewsDesk_Internal&article_num=122206-1 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Astronauts Joan Higgrtdy work the controls of the [[Canadarm2]] in the [[International Space Station]]'s [[Destiny laboratory]]]]
On the third spacewalk, Williams was outside the station for 6 hours and 40 minutes to complete three spacewalks in nine days. She has logged 29 hours and 17 minutes in four spacewalks, eclipsing the record held by [[Kathryn C. Thornton]] for most spacewalk time by a woman.<ref name="bio1" /><ref Name=Malik /> On December 18, 2007, during the fourth [[Extra-vehicular activity|spacewalk]] of [[Expedition 16]], [[Peggy Whitson]] surpassed Williams, with a cumulative EVA time of 32 hours, 36 minutes.<ref name="records4">{{cite web |url=http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-121807a.html |title=Astronauts make 100th station spacewalk |access-date=December 18, 2007 |publisher=CollectSpace |year=2007 |author=CollectSpace}}</ref><ref name="evarecords">{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition16/exp16_eva_121807.html |title=Spacewalkers Find No Solar Wing Smoking Gun |access-date=December 18, 2007 |publisher=NASA |year=2007 |author=NASA}}</ref> In early March 2007, she received a tube of [[wasabi]] in a [[Progress spacecraft]] resupply mission in response to her request for more spicy food. When she opened the tube, which was packaged at one atmospheric pressure, the gel-like paste was forced out in the lower pressure of the ISS. In the free-fall environment, the spicy geyser was difficult to contain.<ref name="spacestation">{{cite web |author=Schneider, Mike |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17421176/ |title=Space station suffers |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |date=2007-03-02 |access-date=2007-03-02}}</ref>
On April 26, 2007, NASA decided to bring Williams back to Earth on the [[STS-117]] mission aboard [[Space Shuttle Atlantis|''Atlantis'']]. She did not break the U.S. single spaceflight record that was recently broken by former crew member Commander [[Michael López-Alegría]], but did break the record for longest single spaceflight by a woman.<ref name="bio1" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arrl.org/?artid=7183 |title=Ham-astronauts setting records in space |publisher=Amateur Radio News |author=Amateur Radio News |date=2007-02-05 |access-date=2007-06-08}}</ref><ref name="stuck">{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17821426/ |title=Astronaut stuck in space — for now |access-date=December 19, 2007 |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |year=2007 |author=Mike Schneider for [[The Associated Press]]}}</ref> Williams served as a mission specialist and returned to Earth on June 22, 2007, at the end of the STS-117 mission. Poor weather at the [[Kennedy Space Center]] in [[Cape Canaveral]] forced mission managers to skip three landing attempts there over previous 24 hours. They then diverted ''Atlantis'' to [[Edwards Air Force Base]] in [[California]], where the shuttle touched down at 3:49 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]], returning Williams home after a record 192-day stay in space.
===First marathon in space===
On April 16, 2007, she ran the first marathon by any person in space.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition14/exp14_boston_marathon.html |title=Race From Space Coincides with Race on Earth |author=Eldora Valentine |publisher=NASA |date=2007-04-06 |access-date=2007-06-08}}</ref> Williams was listed as an entrant for the 2007 [[Boston Marathon]], and completed the distance in four hours and 24 minutes.<ref>{{cite web |author= |publisher=Zee News Limited |url=http://www.zeenews.com/znnew/articles.asp?aid=366217&ssid=27&sid=ENV |title=Sunita Williams Runs Marathon in Space |date=2007-04-17 |access-date=2007-06-08}}</ref><ref name="marathon">{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17862610/ |title=Astronaut to run Boston Marathon — in space |access-date=December 19, 2007 |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |year=2007 |author=Jimmy Golen for [[The Associated Press]]}}</ref><ref name="release">{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/johnson/news/releases/2007/H07-078.html |title=NASA Astronaut to Run Boston Marathon in Space |access-date=December 19, 2007 |publisher=NASA |year=2007 |author=NASA}}</ref> The other crew members cheered her on and gave her oranges during the race. Williams' sister, Dina Pandya, and fellow astronaut [[Karen L. Nyberg]] ran the marathon on Earth, and Williams received updates on their progress from Mission Control. In 2008, Williams participated in the Boston Marathon again, this time on Earth.
===Expeditions 32 and 33=== [[File:Expedition 32 Flight Engineer Sunita Williams exercises on COLBERT.jpg|thumb|250px|Williams exercises on [[Treadmill with Vibration Isolation Stabilization|COLBERT]] during ISS Expedition 32]] [[File:ISS-32 American EVA b6 Sunita Williams.jpg|thumb|250px|Sunita Williams, Expedition 32 flight engineer, appears to touch the bright sun during a spacewalk conducted on September 5, 2012.]]
Williams launched from the [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]] on July 15, 2012, as part of [[Expedition 32]]/[[Expedition 33|33]]. Her Russian spacecraft [[Soyuz TMA-05M]] docked with the ISS for a four-month stay at the orbiting outpost on July 17, 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-industry/et-cetera/sunita-williams-spacecraft-docks-with-iss/articleshow/15015460.cms |title=Sunita Williams' spacecraft docks with ISS |date=July 17, 2012 |work=The Times Of India}}</ref> The docking of the Soyuz occurred at 4:51 GMT as the ISS flew over [[Kazakhstan]] at an altitude of 252 miles. The hatchway between the Soyuz spacecraft and the ISS was opened at 7:23 GMT and Williams floated into the ISS to begin her duties as a member of the Expedition 32 crew. She was accompanied on the Soyuz TMA-05M spacecraft by [[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]] (JAXA) astronaut [[Aki Hoshide]] and Russian [[cosmonaut]] [[Yuri Malenchenko]]. Williams served as commander of the ISS during her stay onboard ISS Expedition 33, succeeding [[Gennady Padalka]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-09-17/science/33901492_1_commander-gennady-padalka-joe-acaba-sergei-revin |title=Sunita Williams takes over command at International Space Station |date=2012-09-17 |work=The Times Of India}}</ref> She became the commander of the [[International Space Station]] on September 17, 2012, being only the second woman to achieve the feat.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/indianamerican-astronaut-sunita-williams-takes-over-command-at-space-station/1003686/ |title=Indian-American astronaut Sunita williams takes over command at space station |publisher=Indian Express |date= |access-date=2012-09-17}}</ref> Also in September 2012, she became the first person to do a triathlon in space, which coincided with the Nautica Malibu Triathlon held in Southern [[California]].<ref name="space.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.space.com/17643-space-triathlon-astronaut-sunita-williams.html|title=Space triathlon with Sunita}}</ref> She used the [[International Space Station]]'s own treadmill and stationary bike, and for the swimming portion of the race, she used the Advanced Resistive Exercise Device (ARED) to do weightlifting and resistance exercises that approximate swimming in microgravity. After 'swimming' half a mile (0.8 km), 'biking' 18 miles (29 km), and 'running' 4 miles (6.4 km), Williams finished with a time of one hour, 48 minutes and 33 seconds, as she reported.<ref name="space.com" />
She returned to earth with fellow astronauts Flight Engineers [[Yuri Malenchenko]] and [[Aki Hoshide]] on November 19, 2012, touching down in the town of [[Arkalyk, Kazakhstan]]. Helicopters joined the search-and-recovery crew to assist them, as their capsule parachuted down some {{convert|35|km}} from the planned touchdown site due to a procedural delay.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/sunita-williams-returns-to-earth/1/229750 |title=Sunita Williams returns to Earth after 4 months in space |author=[[Staff writer]] |work=India Today |date=November 19, 2012}}</ref>
===Space-walks=== {{As of|2012|8}}, Williams has made seven spacewalks totaling 50 hours and 40 minutes,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition32/exp32_eva3.html |title=Williams, Hoshide Complete MBSU Installation |author=NASA |publisher=nasa.gov |date=September 6, 2012 |access-date=September 7, 2012}}</ref> putting Williams in No. 9 on the [[List of cumulative spacewalk records|list of most experienced spacewalkers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/station/exp33/121101eva/ |title=Astronauts bypass station cooling system on spacewalk |author=William Harwood |date=November 1, 2012 |access-date=November 4, 2012}}</ref> On August 30, 2012, Williams and JAXA astronaut Hoshide ventured outside the ISS to conduct US EVA-18. They removed and replaced the failing Main Bus Switching Unit-1 (MBSU-1), and installed a thermal cover onto Pressurized Mating Adapter-2 (PMA-2).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2012/07/soyuz-tma-05m-launch-trio-international-space-station/ |title=Soyuz TMA-05M launches trio to the International Space Station |publisher=NASAspaceflight.com |author=Pete Harding, Chris Bergin and William Graham |date=July 14, 2012 |access-date=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
===Commercial Crew program=== In July 2015, NASA announced Williams as one of the first astronauts for [[Commercial Crew Development|U.S. Commercial spaceflights]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-selects-astronauts-for-first-us-commercial-spaceflights-0 | title=NASA Selects Astronauts for First U.S. Commercial Spaceflights | author=NASA| publisher=nasa.gov|date=July 9, 2015}}</ref> Subsequently, she has started working with [[Boeing]] and [[SpaceX]] to train in their commercial crew vehicles, along with other chosen astronauts. In August 2018 she was assigned to the first mission flight, [[CTS-1]], to the [[International Space Station]] of the Boeing [[CST-100 Starliner]].<ref name=nasacc_crew>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-assigns-crews-to-first-test-flights-missions-on-commercial-spacecraft |title=NASA Assigns Crews to First Test Flights, Missions on Commercial Spacecraft |date=August 3, 2018 |access-date=August 4, 2018 |website=NASA}}</ref>
==Personal life== She was a member of [[Society of Experimental Test Pilots]].
Williams is married to Michael J. Williams, a [[Federal law enforcement in the United States|Federal police officer]] in [[Oregon]]. The two have been married for more than 20 years, and both flew [[helicopter]]s in the early days of their careers. She had a pet [[Jack Russell Terrier]] named Gorby (deceased) who was featured with her on the ''[[Dog Whisperer]]'' television show on the [[National Geographic Channel]] on November 12, 2010.<ref>[http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/series/dog-whisperer/4533/Overview Dog Whisperer: Astronaut Dogs & Mongo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714155714/http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/series/dog-whisperer/4533/Overview |date=July 14, 2011 }}, National Geographic Channel, November 12, 2010.</ref> In 2012, Williams expressed a desire to adopt a girl from [[Ahmedabad]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-06-27/ahmedabad/32440687_1_sunita-williams-deepak-pandya-girl-child-campaign |title=Astronaut Sunita Williams to adopt Gujarati girl |date=June 27, 2012 |work=The Times Of India}}</ref>
In September 2007, Williams visited India. She went to the [[Sabarmati Ashram]] and her ancestral village [[Jhulasan]] in [[Gujarat]]. She was awarded the [[Vallabhbhai Patel|Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel]] Vishwa Pratibha Award by the World Gujarati Society,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/sunita-gets-vishwa-pratibha-award/219791/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130122173955/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/sunita-gets-vishwa-pratibha-award/219791/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-22 |title=Sunita Williams |accessdate=2012-05-24 }}</ref> the first [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|person of Indian descent]] who was not an Indian citizen to be presented the award. On October 4, 2007, Williams spoke at the [[American Embassy School]], and then met [[Manmohan Singh]], the then [[Prime Minister of India]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Astronaut Sunita Williams Visits AES |publisher=American Embassy School |author=American Embassy School |date=2007-10-05 |url=http://202.54.248.150/aesnews/?p=10 |accessdate=2007-10-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011163333/http://202.54.248.150/aesnews/?p=10 |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref> <center> <gallery> File:Suni Williams with a student at delhi.jpg|Williams at the Nehru Memorial in [[Delhi]] File:Sunita Lyn Williams - Science City - Kolkata 2013-04-02 7515.JPG|April 2013 in [[Science City Kolkata]] File:Sunita Williams with Narayan Ramdas Iyer.JPG|Williams with [[Narayan Ramdas Iyer]] at [[New Delhi]] </gallery> </center>
In October 2014, Williams visited [[Slovenia]]. During her stay, amongst other things, she paid a visit to the Astronomical Society Vega in [[Ljubljana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.arnes.si/~gljsentvid10/aktualno_2014.html|title=Sunita visits Slovenia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ava.rtvslo.si/predvajaj/porocila-ob-petih/ava2.174299506/|title=Slovenia visit}}</ref>
On June 7, 2017, The [[Needham, Massachusetts|Needham]] School Committee voted unanimously to name the town's new elementary school the Sunita L. Williams Elementary School.
==Honors and awards== * [[Navy Commendation Medal]] * [[Navy and Marine Corps Achievement Medal]] * [[Humanitarian Service Medal]] * [[NASA Spaceflight Medal]] * [[Medal "For Merit in Space Exploration"]], [[Government of Russia]] (2011) * [[Padma Bhushan]], [[Government of India]] (25 June 2008)<ref>{{cite web |title=Sunita Williams receives Padma Bhushan |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2008/jul/05sunita.htm |access-date=July 5, 2008}}</ref> * Honorary Doctorate, [[Gujarat Technological University]] (2011)<ref>{{cite web |title=Sunita Williams conferred with Honorary Doctorate by Gujarat Technological University, India (2013) |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/sunita-williams-to-get-her-honorary-doctorate-at-gtu/1095560/}}</ref> * [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Slovenia|Golden Order for Merits]], [[Government of Slovenia]] (20 May 2013)<ref>{{cite web |title=Predsednik republike podpisal ukaz o podelitvi odlikovanja Suniti Williams |url=http://www.up-rs.si/up-rs/uprs.nsf/objave/2D38E66908849261C1257B6D0057998A?OpenDocument |accessdate=May 20, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of Asian Americans#Space|List of Asian American astronauts]] * [[List of female astronauts]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Swati Kiranam | image = Swathi Kiranam.jpg | director = [[K. Viswanath]] | producer = [[V. Madhusudhan Rao]] | writer =[[M. V. S. Haranatha Rao]] (dialogue)
[[Jandhyala Subramanya Sastry|Jandhyala]] (dialogue)
[[Vennelakanti]] (lyrics)
[[Sirivennela Seetarama Sastry]] (lyrics)
[[C. Narayana Reddy]] (lyrics)
Madugula Nagaphani Sharma (lyrics) | story = K. Viswanath | screenplay = K. Viswanath | Lyrics = [[Vennelakanti]]
[[Sirivennela Seetarama Sastry]]
[[C. Narayana Reddy]] | starring = [[Mammootty]]
[[Raadhika Sarathkumar]]
[[Master Manjunath]]
[[Jayanthi (actress)|Jayanthi]]
[[Sakshi Ranga Rao]]
[[Dharmavarapu Subramanyam]]
Ananth | editor = G. G. Krishna Rao | cinematography = Kasthoori | distributor = Swathi Productions | studio = Meher Chaithanya Niketan Trust, Meher Nagar | released = {{Film date|1992|01|01|df=y}} | runtime = 130 minutes | language = Telugu | music = [[K. V. Mahadevan]] }} '''''Swati Kiranam''''' (English:'''Dawn of Light''') is a 1992 [[Telugu film|Telugu]] [[drama film|musical drama film]] directed by [[K. Viswanath]]. Produced by [[V. Madhusudhan Rao]], the film starred [[Mammootty]], [[Master Manjunath]] and [[Raadhika]]. The film is about an egotistical [[music teacher]] envious of the extraordinary talent of his [[Child prodigy|prodigious]] young disciple. The film was showcased among the Indian panorama section, at the 1992 [[International Film Festival of India]], the [[Asia Pacific Film Festival]], the [[Moscow Film Festival]] and the [[Annapurna International School of Film and Media|AISFM Film Festival]].[http://www.aisfm.edu.in/blog/2014/the-films-of-k-viswanath/ The films of K. Viswanath — AISFM Blog][http://iffi.nic.in/Dff2011/FrmIP1992Award.aspx?PdfName=IP1992.pdf Directorate of Film Festival] The film has garnered the [[Filmfare Award for Best Music Director – Telugu|Filmfare Award for Best Music Direction]] and the [[National Film Award for Best Female Playback Singer]].[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sv-7_VKFGC8 Swati Kiranam (1992) - Full Length Telugu Film - Mammootty - Radhika - Master Manjunath - YouTube] The film was dubbed into Malayalam as ''Pranavam''.https://www.malayalachalachithram.com/movie.php?i=2640 ==Plot== The film starts with a shabby old man living as a recluse near a famous temple. When he ventures out into the village, he is beaten by the shepherds who believe that he is a thief. When they hand him over to the police, the officer in charge identifies him as a once-famous musician, Anantha Rama Sharma ([[Mammooty]]), hailed as Sangeeta Samrat (Emperor of music), who has been missing for four years. The inspector RadhaKrishna ([[Achyuth]]) informs his aunt ([[Jayanthi (actress)|Jayanthi]]), who teaches music in his native village, of this and the past of Anantha Sharma is narrated through flashback. ; Flashback begins Anantha Rama Sharma is a widely respected Carnatic singer with a big ego. This is established when he rejects the ''[[Padma Shri]]'' bestowed upon him by the Government of India, as he believes that the other awardees are not worthy to be mentioned alongside him. Gangadhar ([[Master Manjunath]]) lives in the same village. He rejects the society's norms (taking music classes and going to school) and spends his time sitting by the riverside. The river inspires him to sing many songs in different tunes. His music teacher, also the policeman's aunt, recognizes his talent and tries to nurture it. His school teacher (the music teacher's brother) is also fond of Gangadhar. Gangadhar wants to become a great singer, like Ananta Sharma, and his father ([[Dharmavarapu Subrahmanyam]]) encourages him. His day comes when Anantha Sharma is honored in an auditorium. Gangadhar sings a song ("Aanathi Neeyara") in honor of Anantha Sharma, which many consider to be much better than any of Anantha Sharma's works. The boy is hailed as a child prodigy by everyone including Anantha Sharma's wife. Anantha Sharma wants to imprison Gangadhar's talents. So he asks Gangadhar to stay in his house and learn music as one must be well-experienced to sing on stage. Anantha Sharma goes to the extent of copying one of Gangadhar's tunes and singing it on stage to win back his glory. But Gangadhar and Ananta's wife find this out. He now feels guilty and defends himself by saying that he did it as he was afraid this child would destroy his name and fame. In this emotional moment, he suffers a heart-attack. To show his gratitude towards his adopted mother, Gangadhar kills himself so that there is no competition for Anantha Sharma. The incident shocks the villagers and they call Anantha Sharma a murderer. To escape their wrath and insults, he runs away and becomes a recluse. ;Flashback ends Ananta Sharma is still unconscious while in the police station. When he awakes, he finds himself in the house of Gangadhar's music teacher. The music teacher's husband tells him that they have forgiven him and asks him to return to his house. At his house, he finds his wife giving music classes (an institute named "Gangadhar Music Academy") for young children. He sits down amongst the children learning the music basics from his wife. The movie ends with a scene when a young girl next to him chides him gently by correcting his way of singing a basic song note. ==Soundtrack== {{Track listing | headline = Songs | extra_column = Singer(s) | all_lyrics = [[Sirivennela Sitaramasastri]], [[Vennelakanti]], [[C. Narayana Reddy]] & Madugula Nagaphani Sharma | all_music = [[K. V. Mahadevan]] | title1 = Aanathi Neeyara | extra1 = Vani Jayaram | title2 = Jaliga Jabilamma | extra2 = [[Vani Jayaram]], [[K. S. Chithra]] | title3 = Konda Konallo Loyallo | extra3 = Vani Jayaram | title4 = Om Guru | note4 = Shloka | extra4 = Vani Jayaram | title5 = Pranati Pranati Pranati | note5 = male | extra5 = [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]], [[K. S. Chithra]] | title6 = Pranati Pranati Pranati | note6 = Child | extra6 = Vani Jayaram | title7 = Sangeetha Sahitya Samalankrute | extra7 = S. P. Balasubrahmanyam | title8 = Shivani Bhavani Sarvani | note8 = male | extra8 = S. P. Balasubrahmanyam | title9 = Shivani Bhavani Sarvani | note9 = child | extra9 = Vani Jayaram | title10 = Shruti Neevu | extra10 = Vani Jayaram, K. S. Chithra | title11 = Theli Manchu Karigindi | extra11 = Vani Jayaram | title12 = Vaishnavi Bhargavi | extra12 = Vani Jayaram }} ==Awards== {{awards table}} |- | 1992 | [[Vani Jayaram]] (for song "Aanathi Neeyara")[http://www.raaga.com/channels/telugu/movie/A0000059.html Swathi Kiranam Songs - Swathi Kiranam Telugu Movie Songs - Telugu Songs Lyrics Trailer Videos, Preview Stills Reviews] | [[National Film Award for Best Female Playback Singer]] | {{won}} |- |1992 | [[K. V. Mahadevan]] |[[Filmfare Award for Best Music Director – Telugu]] | {{won}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0250012|Swati Kiranam}} {{Kasinathuni Viswanath}} [[Category:1992 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Telugu-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by K. Viswanath]] [[Category:Indian nonlinear narrative films]] [[Category:Films about the arts]] [[Category:Indian musical films]] [[Category:Films about classical music and musicians]] [[Category:Telugu film scores by K. V. Mahadevan]] [[Category:Indian drama films]] [[Category:Telugu-language films dubbed in Malayalam]] [[te:స్వాతి కిరణం]]

February 1966|accessdate=10 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303032708/http://www.rba.gov.au/calculator/annualDecimal.html|archive-date=3 March
